title: How to Build a Folding Screen

steps.headline: Gather 3 plantation-style shutters.
steps.description: If buying new shutters, purchase 3 of the same size. If you're buying salvaged shutters, trim them so that they are uniform in size.

steps.headline: Lay the 3 shutters across 2 sawhorses with the top edges aligned.
steps.description: Clamp them together in several places so that they will not move while you do any necessary repairs.

steps.headline: Examine the shutters and repair as necessary, using wood putty to fill in holes or cracks.
steps.description: Sand smooth and, if desired, apply the finish of your choice. Allow the finish to dry, periodically opening and shutting the louvers so they do not get fixed in 1 position.

steps.headline: Lay 2 shutters side-by-side, face-up, on a worktable.
steps.description: Measure down approximately 12 in. (30.5 cm) from the top right side of the 1st shutter and make a pencil mark. Measure the same distance from the bottom of the shutter and make another mark. These marks are where your hinges will be placed.

steps.headline: Align the middle hole of 1 hinge on the top mark, and use that as a guide to mark the other 2 holes of the hinge.
steps.description: Repeat on the bottom hinge and on the left side of the 2nd door.

steps.headline: Pre-drill screw holes with an electric drill, and fasten the hinges on the front of the 1st 2 shutters using a screwdriver or your electric drill fitted with a screwdriver bit.
Turn the shutters face down with the 2 already hinged together on your right side.
steps.description: Attach the hinges for these shutters exactly as you did before except that these go on the back so that the screen can fold properly.

steps.headline: Attach vinyl furniture glides on the left and right bottom edges of the 2 end panels to protect your floors.
steps.description: This is especially helpful if you are using your screen as a portable room divider or privacy screen.
